Dear Ms. Skinner:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff grabbed youth and pushed him, then put him in a headlock.
Youth had an injury near the right side of his mouth.
Investigation On 12/23/24 the agency self-reported an incident. It was reported
Youth A was bouncing a basketball in the hallway. Staff 1 directed
Youth A to stop. Youth A ignored Staff 1. Staff 1 physically
assaulted Youth A by punching him, grabbing him, and pushing
him up against a door. Staff 1 put Youth A in a head lock. They
were separated by another staff and Staff 1 was sent home
immediately. Youth A had an injury to his face near his mouth and
the right side of his chin. Youth A refused a medical clearance
from the facility nurse.
Interviews:
Former Chief Administrator sent a notification email to DCWL
on 12/22/24 regarding the incident. Former Chief Administrator
reported they reviewed video of the incident and immediately sent
Staff 1 home on administrative leave. Staff 1’s termination was
pending. The incident was reported to MDHHS and law
enforcement. Youth A had some scrapes on his chin and a cut on
his lip. Youth A refused a medical evaluation.
MDHHS Worker sent an email to DCWL and reported Youth A
was observed on 12/23/34 and photos were taken of his injuries.
Attempts to interview Staff 1 by phone occurred on 12/30/24,
1/15/25, and 1/27/25. Staff 1 did not return any calls. Staff 1’s
employment was terminated on 1/2/25.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 was present during the
2

incident and observed Youth A bouncing a basketball in the
hallway. Staff 2 asked Youth A to stop, but he did not listen. Youth
A continued bouncing the ball off the floor, walls, and windows.
Staff 2 asked again and explained he could break something with
the ball. Staff 1 was sitting by Youth B’s door and observed Staff 2
making multiple requests to stop bouncing the ball. Staff 1 then
swiped the ball from Youth A. Staff 2 stated it was a little fuzzy
about what happened next, as some other staff and youth could
be heard coming up the stairs. Staff 2 recalled hearing Youth A
swear at and push Staff 1. Staff 2 observed Youth A and Staff 1
become entangled. Staff 2 approached them and observed Staff
1’s arm around Youth A’s neck. Staff 2 tried to pry them apart,
while telling them to stop. Staff 2 could not pull them apart and
called for a supervisor. Staff 1, Staff 2, Youth A, and Youth B were
the only people present at that time. When the two separated,
Youth A had blood on his face. Staff 1 stated he thought his
bracelet hit Youth A’s face in the struggle. Staff 2 did not witness
any punches. Staff 2 verified Staff 1 did not use proper Crisis
Prevention Institute (CPI) techniques. Staff 2 recalled Staff 1 was
the one-to-one staff for Youth B. Staff 2 was unsure why Staff 1
interjected himself in the situation and wished he would have let
Staff 2 handle it.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 3 reported when she
arrived on the floor Staff 1 already had Youth A in a hold. It was
not a regular CPI hold as staff were trained to use. In addition,
staff were not allowed to do one person holds and always had to
call for assistance if a hold was necessary. Staff 1 had his arms
over Youth A’s shoulder while holding him. Staff 3 could not recall
exactly what else Staff 1 was doing. Youth A was yelling that he
was going to attack Staff 1 when he was let go. Staff 3 called for a
supervisor. Staff 1 then let go of Youth A. Youth A had some
blood on his face, although she was unsure where it was coming
from. Staff 3 recalled Youth A was breathing and talking normally
while in the hold.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported they arrived
on the floor and observed Staff 1 holding Youth A in a headlock.
The hold was not a proper CPI technique. Staff 4 initially thought
Staff 1 was breaking up a fight. However, it became apparent that
was not the case as Youth B said Staff 1 punched Youth A,
slammed him, and put him in a headlock. Staff 1 later said he told
Youth A to go to his room and his bracelet hit Youth A on the lip.
Staff 4 stated that story did not make sense. Staff 1 was the one-
3

to-one staff for Youth B that day. It did not make sense for him to
be involved in a situation with Youth A. Staff 4 observed Youth A
to have a “busted lip”, blood on his face, and some marks on his
neck.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth A stated on 12/22/24
he was upstairs bouncing a ball. Staff 2 asked him to stop. Staff 1
yelled at Youth A to stop bouncing the ball. Staff 1 then slapped
the ball away. Youth A pushed Staff 1. Staff 1 punched Youth A
into the face. They began fighting and Youth A was hit in the lip.
Staff 1 had his hands around Youth A’s neck. Youth A could not
breathe for a few seconds, then Staff 1 let go. Staff 1 held Youth A
for less than a minute. Youth A was aware Staff 1 was not
following policy. Youth A reported he felt safe at the facility with
Staff 1 gone.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 12/30/24 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B indicated he did not
recall anything and refused to be interviewed any further.
Contact occurred with MDHHS Worker on 1/9/25 and 1/28/25.
MDHHS Worker reported that a Kids Talk interview was
scheduled for Youth A. However, it never occurred as Youth A
was moved from the facility and his new placement had not
responded to requests to reschedule. MDHHS Worker also
reported she attempted to contact the assigned Detroit Police
Department Detective for an update on any criminal charges.
However, she had not received a response.
Video review:
Youth A was walking down the hallway, bouncing a basketball.
Staff 1 stood from his chair and approached Youth A. Staff 1
knocked the ball away from Youth A. Staff 1 pushed on Youth A’s
face and shoulder. Youth A attempted to walk away. Staff 1
continued to follow Youth A as Youth A turned and pushed Staff 1.
Staff 1 then pushed Youth A into the wall, then into a door. Staff 2
ran down the hallway to intervene. Although the view was partially
obstructed by a pipe in the ceiling, Staff 1 could be seen standing
and wrestling with Youth A. Staff 2 and Staff 3 tried to pull them
apart. Youth B was standing in the hallway watching. Staff 1, Staff
2, Staff 3 and Youth A were standing together by the door. Due to
the blocked view, it was unclear what occurred. However, Staff 4
and additional youth entered the unit and walked past the
situation. Supervisor also entered the unit at that time and the
4

group dispersed. From the time Staff 1 first engaged with Youth A,
until they separated was approximately 48 seconds.
Documentation:
• Employee file review for Staff 1:
o Hired 11/4/24
o Completed Orientation training on 11/7/24.
o Completed Building Bridges Initiative Six Core
Strategies training on 11/6/24 and 11/7/24.
o Completed CPI training on 11/13/24.
o Signed “Staff Acknowledgment of Behavior
Management” on 11/7/24.
o No disciplinary action on file prior to this incident.
o Termination letter dated 1/2/25
• Incident report dated 12/22/24, authored by Supervisor.
The incident report was consistent with the information
provided during interviews with Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4.
The report indicated Supervisor did not witness the
incident, but did review the video, and Staff 1 was
immediately sent home on administrative leave.
• Behavior Support and Management policy indicated staff
are to use non-violent restrictive intervention to contain a
client’s acute physical behavior, to maximize safety and
minimize harm. This is only to be used to protect client or
others from unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior
that places them at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs. Staff are to use CPI non-
violent crisis intervention methods as trained.
Analysis A violation was found based on staff interviews and video review,
Staff 1 used improper behavior management techniques with
Youth A, causing injury.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
